Name: Architectural Concepts
Objective: This view organizes weaknesses according to common architectural security tactics. It is intended to assist architects in identifying potential mistakes that can be made when designing software.

Audience.Description: Architects that are part of a software development team may find this view useful as the weaknesses are organized by known security tactics, aiding the arcitect in embedding security throughout the design process instead of discovering weaknesses after the software has been built.
Educators may use this view as reference material when discussing security by design or architectural weaknesses, and the types of mistakes that can be made.

References.Title: A Catalog of Security Architecture Weaknesses.
References.Publication: 2017 IEEE International Conference on Software Architecture (ICSA)

References.Title: Understanding Software Vulnerabilities Related to Architectural Security Tactics: An Empirical Investigation of Chromium, PHP and Thunderbird.
References.Publication: 2017 IEEE International Conference on Software Architecture (ICSA)

MappingNotes.Rationale: This entry is a View. Views are not weaknesses and therefore inappropriate to describe the root causes of vulnerabilities.
MappingNotes.Comments: Use this View or other Views to search and navigate for the appropriate weakness.

Notes.Note: The top level categories in this view represent the individual tactics that are part of a secure-by-design approach to software development. The weaknesses that are members of each category contain information about how each is introduced relative to the software's architecture. Three different modes of introduction are used: Omission - caused by missing a security tactic when it is necessary. Commission - refers to incorrect choice of tactics which could result in undesirable consequences. Realization - appropriate security tactics are adopted but are incorrectly implemented.
